author: cruscio
body:
If links in a Link header do not contain a space between `;` and `rel` then invoke-webrequest fails to populate the RelationLink property 
```
<http://localhost:8080/PowerShell?test=linkheader&maxlinks=5&linknumber=1>; rel="self"
<http://localhost:8080/PowerShell?test=linkheader&maxlinks=5&linknumber=1>;rel="self"
```
Not having a space is valid (more appropriate, even) per the specification: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988 page 6

### For reference 
  #5265 [Feature] Add Multiple Link Header Support 
#### Code
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/9e99d596212bc6e2b92af6700889f7698492474d/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility/commands/utility/WebCmdlet/CoreCLR/WebRequestPSCmdlet.CoreClr.cs#L835
#### Test
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/9e99d596212bc6e2b92af6700889f7698492474d/test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility/WebCmdlets.Tests.ps1#L797

I think the appropriate fix would be to change `\\s` to `\\s*` to allow for 0 or more whitespace rather than requiring a single whitespace 

- Current regex not working: https://regex101.com/r/QbglHf/1
- Proposed modification: https://regex101.com/r/QbglHf/2

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
Hmm rfc has 

```none
link-value     = "<" URI-Reference ">" *( ";" link-param )
```

The ` *` is interesting. I couldn't find whether they mean "zero or more" spaces or "one or more" spaces. I'm not sure it really matters. The current regex definitely doesn't cover either. 😃 

I'm ok with the proposed change.

comments.author: cruscio
comments.body:
> whether they mean "zero or more" spaces or "one or more" spaces

At the risk of being pedantic, the specification doesn't _explicitly_ allow _any_ whitespace there. The `*()` indicates one or more instances of `;link-param` can follow `<URI-Reference>` - with no whitespace after the `>` or bfore the `;` .

That said, RFC5988 follows RFC2616 ABNF notation, which _implicitly_ allows for linear white space (LWS) between any two adjacent tokens or quoted-strings, and between adjacent words and separators.

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-2.2
```
LWS            = [CRLF] 1*( SP | HT )
SP             = <US-ASCII SP, space (32)>
HT             = <US-ASCII HT, horizontal-tab (9)>
```

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-2.1
```
implied *LWS
      The grammar described by this specification is word-based. Except
      where noted otherwise, linear white space (LWS) can be included
      between any two adjacent words (token or quoted-string), and
      between adjacent words and separators, without changing the
      interpretation of a field. At least one delimiter (LWS and/or

      separators) MUST exist between any two tokens (for the definition
      of "token" below), since they would otherwise be interpreted as a
      single token.
```
In `link-value     = "<" URI-Reference ">" *( ";" link-param )`, `";"` is a quoted string and `link-param` is a token, so the space is implicitly allowed between them, but not required.

Anyway, I think we're on the same page; just wanted to clarify the interpretation of the RFC

comments.body: Ugh.. one of these days I will learn how to properly translate RFC's into actual things... Today is not that day. Thanks for explaining.

title: Link Header pagination fails when there's no space between ';' and 'rel'
